items.title: SPARQL Query Return Wrong Result
items.body:
I can reproduce the wrong result with the following example:

```
import rdflib
from pprint import pprint

data = """
@prefix ex: <http://example.org/> .
@prefix rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .

ex:CCCC a rdfs:Class ;
    rdfs:subClassOf ex:AAAA .

ex:DDDD rdfs:subClassOf ex:BBBB,
        ex:AAAA .
"""

g = rdflib.Graph().parse( data = data, format = 'ttl' )

# print( f"{g.serialize( format = 'ttl' ).decode( 'utf8' )}" )

query = """
        PREFIX sch:  <http://schema.org/>
        PREFIX rdf:  <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>
        PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
        
        SELECT ?class ?subclass
        WHERE {        
                ?class rdfs:subClassOf+ ?subclass .                               
        }
        ORDER BY ?class ?subclass
        """

qres = g.query( query )

for row in qres:    
              
    aclass    = str( row['class'] )
    subclass  = str( row['subclass'] )
    print( f"{aclass:30s} {subclass:50s}" )  
```

This outputs:

```
http://example.org/CCCC        http://example.org/AAAA                           
http://example.org/CCCC        http://example.org/BBBB                           
http://example.org/DDDD        http://example.org/AAAA                           
http://example.org/DDDD        http://example.org/BBBB   
```

The output declares there is a subClassOf path from CCCC to BBBB and there is not. 

I downloaded a SPARQL playground from http://sparql-playground.sib.swiss which is trivial to get up and running on a local machine and tried the same data and query. The results were:

```
<http://example.org/CCCC>	<http://example.org/AAAA>
<http://example.org/DDDD>	<http://example.org/AAAA>
<http://example.org/DDDD>	<http://example.org/BBBB>
```

which is *exactly* what one expects.

items.title: Like .triples() but return a graph
items.body:
My use case is that I would like to chain multiple operations like this:

    graph.triples().add().remove().serialize()

The problem is that `triples` returns an iterator, not a graph object. I do understand that `triples` needs an iterator to deal with the possible situation of having too many results at once. But assuming that I'm only retrieving a small number of triples, for example a single node like this `.triples(subject, None, None)` it would be nice to be able to chain those operations. Is is possible to do something like this?

items.title: Missing Content-Type header for SPARQLConnector update method (?)
items.body:
In rdflib 4.2.2 the SPARQLWrapper added an applicable content-type header when sending queries and updates to a SPARQL endpoint.
The 5.0.0 the SPARQLConnector does not add a content-type and, since the GraphDB we use as SPARQL endpoint rejects update requests when Content-Type: application/sparql-update is not added to the header, I had to monkey patch the update method to forcebily add the content type to the header.

I also tried to add a headers parameter with the content-type to the SPARQLUpdateStore parameter when constructing a SPARQLUpdateStore instance, but this then the content type is also used for query request, which results in rejected query requests in case the store instance is used for querying.

Should the the content type be added by the SPARQLConnector like the SPARQLWrapper did or am i missing an other intended solution?

Best regards,
Arnoud

However, the clause LIMIT and OFFSET inside the graph CLAUSE breaks the translateQuery method.


```
?item ?predicate ?prop .
?prop a ?type

 ?prop a ?type
}

 '''
```

## How to test?

```python
from rdflib.plugins.sparql.parser import Query, UpdateUnit

rq = '''

?prop a ?type
}

{
 SELECT DISTINCT ?item where {
   ?item a ?_type_iri .
 }
}
?item ?predicate ?prop
OPTIONAL {
 ?prop a ?type
}
}
}
'''

translateQuery(Query.parseString(rq, parseAll=True))

?item ?predicate ?prop .
?prop a ?type
}
WHERE {
GRAPH ?_g_iri {
{
 SELECT DISTINCT ?item where {
   ?item a ?_type_iri .
 }
 LIMIT ?_per_page_integer
 OFFSET ?_off_set_integer
}
?item ?predicate ?prop
OPTIONAL {
 ?prop a ?type
}
}
}

translateQuery(Query.parseString(rq, parseAll=True))
```

items.title: Namespace binding applied inconsistently
items.body:
Hi,

I have a small graph with data from dbpedia in file dbpedia_anime_2.ttl (appended as TXT). I want to simplify it by using an additional namespace for dbpedia ressources. I use the following code:

```g2 = Graph()
dbp_ns = Namespace('http://dbpedia.org/resource/')
g2.namespace_manager.bind('dbpres', dbp_ns, replace=True, override=True)

g2.parse("dbpedia_anime_2.ttl", format="turtle")

fh = open ('dbpedia_anime_3.ttl', 'wb')
fh.write(g2.serialize(format="turtle"))
fh.close()
```
which runs fine and creates the file dbpedia_anime_3.ttl (also appended as TXT). 

The problem is, that the new namespace is sometimes applied to an URI and sometimes not. I was expecting RDFlib to consistently shorten all applicable URI using the new namespace.

Am I doing something wrong?

[dbpedia_anime_2.ttl.TXT](https://github.com/RDFLib/rdflib/files/4523416/dbpedia_anime_2.ttl.TXT)
[dbpedia_anime_3.ttl.TXT](https://github.com/RDFLib/rdflib/files/4523417/dbpedia_anime_3.ttl.TXT)

Kind regards,
Magnus

items.title: Future support for Python 2 - poll
items.body:
[rdflib 5.0.0](https://github.com/RDFLib/rdflib/releases/tag/5.0.0) has been [proposed](https://github.com/RDFLib/rdflib/wiki/2020-04-03-Maintainers-Meeting-Minutes#what-do-we-want-to-tell-people) as the last rdflib release to support Python 2 (and 3.4) due to the maintenance overhead of supporting multiple versions and legacy tie-ins that prevent features of Python 3.5+ being utilised.

We would like to find out if there is strong interest in the rdflib development community in supporting Python 2 (and 3.4) going forward.

### Do you agree with dropping support for Python 2 (and 3.4) in future rdflib releases?

*Indicate agreement with thumbs up reaction to this, disagreement with thumbs down. If you disagree, please add a comment to this Issue indicating why.*

items.body:
Hello, I am not a sparql expert. I would want to use a regex match for a string literal ("solutions") with word boundaries around it.

```python
  org = Namespace('http://www.w3.org/ns/org#')
  onet = Namespace('http://bnc-nbc.ca/sw/skos/onet#')
  RDF2 = Namespace('http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#')

  initNs = { 'foaf': FOAF2, 'skos': SKOS, 'rdf': RDF2, 'org': org, 'onet': onet }

            ?skill_group skos:prefLabel ?skill_group_label;

            FILTER(REGEX(?skill_label, "\\bsolutions\\b", "i"))

```

This doesnt match anything, if I remove the word boundaries it does find everything with the literal in it:


I tried being very creative in using escape chars, adding single quotes and using concat.

items.title: Auto-detect RDF type from file extension in parse()
items.body:
`Graph().parse("some-file.ttl", format="turtle")` is a common way to load RDF into an rdflib Graph. We have methods such as `rdflib.util.guess_format()` to guess `format` from the file extensions so what we need now is for `guess_format()` to be triggered automatically if `format` is not given so `parse()` can be used like this:

```
Graph().parse("some-file.ttl")
```

items.title: Automate call to apidoc

milestone.title: rdflib 5.0.0
milestone.description:
5.0! The bright new future!

With strong AI!

items.body:
Currently the apidoc-generated autodoc files are version controlled and inconsistent with the result of the apidoc command in docs/docs.rst . This has resulted in the files being out-of-date. This situation can be resolved by running apidoc as part of the documentation build process. This is possible using the `sphinx.ext.apidoc` module and calling `main` in docs/conf.py

To resolve this issue, add that call to `sphinx.ext.apidoc.main()` to docs/conf.py with appropriate options so the generated docs go into the docs directory, remove the autodoc files checked-in to git, and add .gitignore entries for the files apidoc generates. An example is in [openworm/owmeta](https://github.com/openworm/owmeta).

items.title: 'en_US' is not a valid language tag!
items.body:
rdflib validates langauge tags, and RFC 5646 is mentioned at the top of term.py. Dash is the only valid separator for things like "en-US" in this RFC.

In parsing the actual web, some small fraction of the web uses "en_US" with an underscore. This causes an exception deep in rdflib, and there's no easy way of fixing it up at runtime.

I'm not a fan of invalid input being silently fixed up, so I'd recommend it being an option and not the default.

term.py:_is_valid_langtag() is the thing that validates.

items.title: DCTERMS.format not working

milestone.title: rdflib 5.0.0
milestone.description:
5.0! The bright new future!

With strong AI!

items.body:
When using the inbuilt DCTERMS namespace, `from rdflib.namespace import DCTERMS`, an error is thrown if the following triple is added to a graph:

```
g.add((r, DCTERMS.format, Literal('application/pdf')))
```
**error**: _AssertionError: Predicate <built-in method format of Namespace object at 0x10e8e2de0> must be an rdflib term_

Presumably there's a Python reserved word 'format' collision somewhere.

Have to do this as a workaround:
```
g.add((r, URIRef('http://purl.org/dc/terms/format'), Literal('application/pdf')))
```

items.title: SPARQL result parser not handling ;charset= in Content-type

milestone.title: rdflib 5.0.0
milestone.description:
5.0! The bright new future!

With strong AI!

items.body:
We recently upgraded the Jetty server that hosts Blazegraph. That server now sends a charset in the Content-Type header:

application/sparql-results+json;charset=utf-8

However, the SPARQL result parser plugins are keyed to the unsparsed Content-Type; the relevant key is `application/sparql-results+json`.

milestone.description:
5.0! The bright new future!

With strong AI!

items.body:
>>> from rdflib import Graph
>>> g=Graph()
>>> g.parse(data='<a:> <b:> <c:> .', format='nt') # nquads also fails

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/rdflib/graph.py", line 1039, in parse
    parser.parse(source, self, **args)
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/rdflib/plugins/parsers/nt.py", line 26, in parse
    parser.parse(f)
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/rdflib/plugins/parsers/ntriples.py", line 142, in parse
    raise ParseError("Invalid line: %r" % self.line)
rdflib.plugins.parsers.ntriples.ParseError: Invalid line: u'<a:> <b:> <c:> .'

N3, by contrast, succeeds:

>>> g.parse(data='<a:> <b:> <c:> .', format='n3')

Fix is to change:
uriref = r'<([^:]+:[^\s"<>]+)>'
to:
uriref = r'<([^:]+:[^\s"<>]*)>'
in ntriples.py.

items.body:
Apologies if this is a duplicate of an existing issue - I've found a few Unicode-encoding-caused problems but none seemed to relate to this one.

How can `rdflib` load a resource like [this one](http://dbpedia.org/page/Human%E2%80%93computer_interaction)?

```python
path, page = "http://dbpedia.org/page/", "Human–computer_interaction"
```

The above snippet returns an error (`UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character '\u2013'`), so I've also tried to percent-encode the path of the URL, but then it just seems to get stuck in an infinite loop:

```python
from urllib.parse import quote
graph.load(path+quote(page))
```

items.title: It is possible to create invalid RDF with rdflib
items.body:
I was able to successfully create the following RDF graph:
```
from rdflib import Graph, URIRef, Literal
g = Graph()
g.add((Literal('A'), Literal('B'), Literal('C')))
```
It is serialised into Turtle as follows:
```
@prefix rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#> .
<...>
"Hi" "Hello" "Bye" .
```

And according to [the RDFLib code](https://github.com/RDFLib/rdflib/blob/1503dae6049f0d9b14d9d7f884d8de4cb38b39a3/rdflib/graph.py#L385-L391) it is a valid triple. However, according to the [RDF specification](https://www.w3.org/TR/rdf11-concepts/#section-triples) it is not:
```
An RDF triple consists of three components:

*    the subject, which is an IRI or a blank node
*    the predicate, which is an IRI
*    the object, which is an IRI, a literal or a blank node
```
And indeed when the output Turtle is validated with the [W3C validator](https://www.w3.org/2015/03/ShExValidata/), it produces this error:
```
Expected subject but got literal at line 6.
```

Hence, this bit in the README file is also incorrect:
> The components of the triples are URIs (resources) or Literals (values),

I think this issue deserves a further discussion, and please let me know if I can fix this and raise a PR.

items.title: Issue with Externals library(solid-auth-client)
NTriples can not parse blank node with underscore
items.body:
The ntriples parser is not able to parse blank nodes with wan underscore in the blank label.
If I read the N-Triple standard correctly that should be possible: https://www.w3.org/TR/n-triples/#grammar-production-BLANK_NODE_LABEL

```
[141s] BLANK_NODE_LABEL ::= '_:' (PN_CHARS_U |  [0-9]) ((PN_CHARS |  '.')* PN_CHARS)?
[158s] PN_CHARS_U ::= PN_CHARS_BASE |  '_' |  ':'
[160s] PN_CHARS ::= PN_CHARS_U |  '-' |  [0-9] |  #x00B7 |  [#x0300-#x036F] |  [#x203F-#x2040]
```

This code works:
```
import rdflib
g = rdflib.Graph().parse(data='_:bnode <urn:p> "lit" .', format='ntriples')
```

This code does not work:
```
import rdflib
g = rdflib.Graph().parse(data='_:node_a <urn:p> "lit" .', format='ntriples')
```

Similar to #835 but concerns the underscore.

items.body:
I encountered this issue while working on [pySHACL](https://github.com/RDFLib/pySHACL).
Specifically, this bug is causing a failure in one of the tests in the standard data-shapes-test-suite here [uniqueLang-002-shapes.ttl](https://github.com/w3c/data-shapes/blob/gh-pages/data-shapes-test-suite/tests/core/property/uniqueLang-002-shapes.ttl).
This test relies on the fact that `"1"^^xsd:boolean` is an invalid Literal, and when testing equality of this Literal against RDF True, it should be not equal.

A simple code recreation:
```python
import rdflib
from rdflib.namespace import XSD
fail_bool = rdflib.Literal("1", datatype=XSD.boolean)
true_bool = rdflib.Literal("true", datatype=XSD.boolean)
print("value: {} , datatype: {} ".format(
    str(fail_bool._value), str(fail_bool.datatype)))
try:
    assert not (fail_bool == true_bool),\
        "\"1\" should not equal \"true\""
except AssertionError as a:
    print("assertion fail: \n{}".format(str(a)))
```

This is a more complete example:
https://gist.github.com/ashleysommer/87f0b9660a71de380889f98745af2f74

I've tracked down the problem to this line in the XSDToPython map:
https://github.com/RDFLib/rdflib/blob/5fa18be1231a5e4dfc86ec28f2f754158c6f6f0b/rdflib/term.py#L1484
`lambda i: i.lower() in ['1', 'true']`
should be changed to
`lambda i: i.lower() == 'true'`

items.title: NOW() SPARQL should return an xsd:dateTime with a timezone

milestone.title: rdflib 5.0.0
milestone.description:
5.0! The bright new future!

With strong AI!

items.body:
Currently rdflib implementation of `NOW()` returns a datetime in the server local timezone without specifying it in the literal string. This is not what the SPARQL specification suggests: https://www.w3.org/TR/2013/REC-sparql11-query-20130321/#func-now

The `NOW()` function should probably be changed to return a date time with a timezone

items.title: `rdf:parseType` shouldn't be converted into `rdf:datatype`
items.body:
When parsing a file that has an object with `rdf:parseType`, it is automatically converted into `rdf:datatype`.  `rdf:parseTypes` should be handled explicity instead of converted and they change the xml output:

```xml
<dcterms:description rdf:parseType="Literal">This is a simple description</dcterms:description>
```
gets changed to:

```xml
<dcterms:description rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#XMLLiteral">This is a simple description</dcterms:description>
```

items.title: from_n3 interprets \[a-f0-7] as a hex
items.body:
When submitting a string to `from_n3` that contains a backslash character that is immediately followed by a, b, c, d, e, f, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, or 7, instead of the backslash being escaped (\\), the characters are converted to a hex value (or perceived to be a hex value when encoded).

The code is here:

https://github.com/RDFLib/rdflib/blob/master/rdflib/util.py#L182-L185

Line 185 is actually where the problem occurs.  Here it is isolated in the console:

```console
>>> "\b".encode("raw-unicode-escape").decode("unicode-escape")
'\x08'
>>> "\b".encode("raw-unicode-escape")
b'\x08'
>>> 
```
Note that it is the call to `encode("raw-unicode-escape")` that is the culprit.

I'm not sure where to go from here.  This is a bug in `from_n3` but it is also, obviously, something that is, or likely is, incorrect in the Python encoding codec.

The line in question (185) was added back in 2011 by @takluyver: https://github.com/RDFLib/rdflib/commit/3a62086bb08bb7e083fe22778eb2da7b773f451e#diff-b4eb8b008f7771bbbe2a9c3930853fe4

Does anyone here recall what problem was trying to be solved with the introduction of this call to encode and decode the string?

I'm not against submitting a fix, but this is pretty deep in the rdflib stack, the note describes it as a hack, and I want a better understanding of the issues that preceded the 2011 addition.

Thoughts?

items.title: Rename prefix
items.body:
Love the Python library to make RDF! Keep it going.

One issue I don't know how to fix and I didn't find explicitly in the RDFLib 5.0.0 documentation is renaming a prefix. For example, I have been given a graph from an external source and don't like the way they did their prefixes. Therefore I want to rename the prefix at the start and in the graph. 
This is what I parsed from a link:

``` RDF file in n3 format (INCORRECT)
@prefix rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>.
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix n80: <http://www.opengis.net/ont/geosparql#>.
n80:Geometry rdf:type <http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#Class>;
    rdfs:isDefinedBy <http://www.opengis.net/ont/geosparql#>
.
n80:hasGeometry rdf:type <http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#ObjectProperty>;
    rdfs:isDefinedBy <http://www.opengis.net/ont/geosparql#>
.
```
This is where I want to go:
``` RDF file in n3 format (CORRECT!)
@prefix rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>.
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix geo: <http://www.opengis.net/ont/geosparql#>.
geo:Geometry rdf:type <http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#Class>;
    rdfs:isDefinedBy <http://www.opengis.net/ont/geosparql#>
.
geo:hasGeometry rdf:type <http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#ObjectProperty>;
    rdfs:isDefinedBy <http://www.opengis.net/ont/geosparql#>
.
```
This is how I tried to solve it, but which didn't work.

``` Python Script
from rdflib import Namespace, Graph

buildings_ontology = 'https://bag.basisregistraties.overheid.nl/query/model?format=ttl'
g = Graph()
g.parse(buildings_ontology, format = 'n3')
geo = Namespace('http://www.opengis.net/ont/geosparql#')
g.namespace_manager.bind('n80', geo, override = True, replace=True)
```
How would you rename the prefix at the start and in the graph?

Since I think there is no method or function that does that, I made an issue on GitHub.
For now this issue is fixed by downloading as text and replacing 'n80:' for 'geo:'.

items.title: rdflib.plugins.stores.sparqlstore.SPARQLStore remove returnFormat=XML
items.body:
The class `SPARQLStore` calls this `init` from the `NSSPARQLWrapper` superclass

`super(SPARQLStore, self).__init__(endpoint, returnFormat=XML, **sparqlwrapper_kwargs)`

the problem is that this doesn't allow any other return format other than XML (for example, JSON). The reason is:

- `returnFormat=XML` sets the default returnFormat upstream to XML
- the `query()` functions resets the query setup at every query, using `self.resetQuery()`

so, even if I call `setReturnFormat()` from the base class `SPARQLWrapper`, it has no effect. Results always return as XML. By removing `returnFormat=XML`, I should be allowed to call `SPARQLStore` like this

`SPARQLStore (endpoint='...', returnFormat=JSON`

items.title: rdf:resource pointing to existing URIRef
items.body:
Hi all,

I'm trying to create an RDF file that Zotero accepts, but I am struggling with getting `rdf:resource` properties (?) to show up.

Basically I'm trying to reference an item from a Zotero collection (this probably does not relate to what RDFLib calls "collection"). Collections in Zotero RDF look like this:
```xml
    <z:Collection rdf:about="#collection_6">
        <dc:title>Example</dc:title>
        <dcterms:hasPart rdf:resource="#collection_8"/>
        <dcterms:hasPart rdf:resource="https://www.example.com"/>
        <dcterms:hasPart rdf:resource="#item_426"/>
        <dcterms:hasPart rdf:resource="http://www.example2.com"/>
    </z:Collection>
```

And items such as attachments look like this:
```xml
    <z:Attachment rdf:about="#item_426">
       <z:itemType>attachment</z:itemType>
       <rdf:resource rdf:resource="files/426/filename.pdf"/>
       <dcterms:dateSubmitted>2017-11-28 16:15:48</dcterms:dateSubmitted>
       <dc:title>filename.pdf</dc:title>
       <z:linkMode>1</z:linkMode>
       <link:type>application/pdf</link:type>
    </z:Attachment>
```
So when trying something like `mygraph.add((mycollection, DCTERMS.hasPart, myattachment))` the attachment is instead placed inside the collection (understandably), like so:
```xml
  <z:Collection rdf:about="#collection_6">
    <dc:title>Example</dc:title>
    <dcterms:hasPart>
      <z:Attachment rdf:about="#item_426">
      ...
      </z:Attachment>
    </dcterms:hasPart>
  </z:Collection>
```
I am definitely missing some concepts here but I am not sure what else to search for. Is there a way to get that `<dcterms:hasPart rdf:resource="#item_426"/>` part correctly? Note that, besides collections, attachments also have a similar child `<rdf:resource rdf:resource="files/426/filename.pdf"/>` that I would like to have as well.

Any help is greatly appreciated.

items.title: SPARQLStore does not support non-XML results
items.body:
This is important because some SPARQL stores return IRI-based namespaces, which lxml and etree do not support. Using a JSON result type will circumvent these issues.

There are a number of issues that arise when you attempt this:

```
foo = SPARQLStore(..., returnFormat=SPARQLWrapper.JSON)
```

This causes an error because the returnFormat is also hard-coded as a parameter to the SPARQLWrapper function.

Setting the returnFormat (`setReturnFormat()`) after construction is insufficient because resetQuery() resets it to _defaultReturnFormat. Setting `_defaultReturnFormat` works for the actual wrapper, but sparqlstore.py:318 does not pass the format on to `Result.parse()`:

```
    return Result.parse(res)
```

should be:

```
    return Result.parse(res, format=self.returnFormat)
```

items.title: URIRef comparison with Python `str` fails using `==`
items.body:
URIRef comparison with Python `str` fails in both Python v2 and v3.  
Per-char comparison of URIRef with str and `==` yield distinct values:
```python
import rdflib
from rdflib.namespace import RDF
typeProp = '<' + RDF.type + '>'  # N3/quad type property
prop = '<http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type>'

eq1 = typeProp == prop  # False
eq2 = len(prop) == len(typeProp) and not prop.find(typeProp)
assert eq1 == eq2, '{} vs {}'.format(eq1, eq2)
```
yields:
```sh
>>> assert eq1 == eq2, '{} vs {}'.format(eq1, eq2)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
AssertionError: False vs True
```
Per-char comparison yields the same as inclusion search, but distinct from the equality check, which is confusing:
```python
class Entity(object):
	"""Entity to load RDF tripples"""
	# ATTENTION: type(RDF.type + 'x') is <class 'rdflib.term.URIRef'>, which breaks the str comparison
	#typeProp = '<' + str(RDF.type) + '>'  # N3/quad type property          OK
	typeProp = '<' + RDF.type + '>'  # FAILS str comparison
...
...
            prop = '<http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type>'
            print('extend(), props: \n{}\n{}\neq: {}'.format(prop, Entity.typeProp, prop == Entity.typeProp))
            for i in range(min(len(prop), len(Entity.typeProp))):
                if prop[i] != Entity.typeProp[i]:
                    print('Unequal pos: {}, val: {} ({}) vs {} ({})', i, prop[i], ord(prop[i]), Entity.typeProp[i], ord(Entity.typeProp[i]))
                    break
            else:
                print('len: {} vs {}, eq: {}, index: {}'.format(len(prop), len(Entity.typeProp), prop == Entity.typeProp,
                    prop.find(Entity.typeProp)))
```
yields:
```sh
extend(), props: 
<http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type>
<http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type>
eq: False
len: 49 vs 49, eq: False, index: 0
```
Investigating the cause:
```sh
>>> type(prop)
<type 'str'>
>>> type(typeProp)
<class 'rdflib.term.URIRef'>
```

The workaround is to perform the explicit type casting `typeProp = '<' + str(RDF.type) + '>' `, but this is not the appropriate solution for any scripting language. If `rdflib.term.URIRef` performs implicit casting from `str`, then it should also support at least `str` equality comparison operations in proper way.

items.title: error in example
items.body:
I'm new to this library so I tried the example in the README:
```
>>> import rdflib
INFO:rdflib:RDFLib Version: 4.2.2
>>> g=rdflib.Graph()
>>> g.load('http://dbpedia.org/resource/Semantic_Web')
>>> 
>>> for s,p,o in g:
...     print s,p,o
... 
http://dbpedia.org/resource/Semantic_Web http://dbpedia.org/ontology/wikiPageExternalLink http://www.w3.org/standards/semanticweb/
http://dbpedia.org/resource/Semantic_Web http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#sameAs http://de.dbpedia.org/resource/Semantic_Web
http://dbpedia.org/resource/Nigel_Shadbolt http://dbpedia.org/ontology/field http://dbpedia.org/resource/Semantic_Web
http://dbpedia.org/resource/Semantic_Web http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#label Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 2, in <module>
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode characters in position 0-2: ordinal not in range(128)
```

I was able to get it to work by changing `o` to `o.encode('utf-8')`:
```
import rdflib
g=rdflib.Graph()
g.load('http://dbpedia.org/resource/Semantic_Web')

for s,p,o in g:
    print s,p,o.encode('utf-8')
```

items.title: ENH: sniff() method to detect RDFa, Microdata, or JSONLD in (X)HTML
Parser exceptions should inherit from rdflib.exceptions.Error
items.body:
Currently, not all exceptions raised by RDFLib are inherited from rdflib.exceptions.Error, e.g. rdflib.plugins.parsers.pyRdfa.RDFaError is subclassed directly from exceptions.Exception. It is suboptimal as it complicates client code needed for handling parser errors.
All exceptions raised by RDFLib directly should inherit from rdflib.exceptions.Error.

items.title: Missing dependency: SPARLWrapper
items.body:
Hi,

I'm working on the `pyaff4` used by the Rekall memory forensic framework, and `rdflib` is one of it's dependencies:
https://github.com/google/aff4/blob/master/pyaff4/setup.py#L59
~~~Python
    install_requires=[
        "aff4-snappy == 0.5",
        "rdflib == 4.2.1",
        "intervaltree == 2.1.0",
        "pyblake2 == 0.9.3",
        "expiringdict == 1.1.4"
    ],
~~~

However, once everything is installed, an error is raised while 
 trying to `import rdflib.plugins.stores.sparqlstore`:
https://github.com/google/rekall/blob/master/rekall-core/rekall/plugins/addrspaces/aff4.py#L408

**The error is that `SPARQLWrapper` is missing as a dependency.**

So there is an issue with `rdflib` right now, becaus Pypi also says that `SPARQLWrapper` is listed as a dependency, but it's not being installed.

~~~
$ (venv) pip install rdflib
Collecting rdflib
  Downloading rdflib-4.2.2-py3-none-any.whl (344kB)
    100% |████████████████████████████████| 348kB 2.7MB/s
Collecting isodate (from rdflib)

Collecting pyparsing (from rdflib)
  Using cached pyparsing-2.2.0-py2.py3-none-any.whl
Building wheels for collected packages: isodate
  Running setup.py bdist_wheel for isodate ... done
  Stored in directory: /home/wenzel/.cache/pip/wheels/61/c0/d2/6b4a10c222ba9261ab9872a8f05d471652962284e8c677e5e7
Successfully built isodate
Installing collected packages: isodate, pyparsing, rdflib
Successfully installed isodate-0.5.4 pyparsing-2.2.0 rdflib-4.2.2
~~~

~~~
$ (venv) pip freeze
isodate==0.5.4

Can anybody upload a new version of `rdflib` which fixes this dependency ? :)

Thanks !

items.title: Parsing error on some SPARQL queries
